This is from the same fan base that had 445 consecutive sellouts or somewhere near that number from '95-01  Indian seasons, so it isn't like fans in Cleveland will not support a great product. Three reasons in my mind why Cleveland fans are not supporting Tribe jus yet. 1) Ticket prices are much higher now than when ball park opened in '94 and bleacher seats were $7. Ah the good old days! 2) Cleveland is one hard hit city when it comes job growth. It hasn't been truly good economic times since like the late 60's in Cleveland. The last 5 years have been brutal, so which fans have money to spend on luxury taking family to baseball games? 3) Last year's fade out into a .500 ballclub reminded older fans of the bad old Tribe days from say 60's-80's clubs where Indians would do their usual June swoon. I believe most fans are just making sure this club is for real before they plunk down hard earned cash on this ballclub. If the Indians are still in or near first by July 4th, then fans will come out.....and in droves.

The Indians did have the longest sell-out run in the majors, back in the day.  The Dolans have been very unpopular owners, and I think there is a lack of trust that great players - like Perez - won't be "going somewhere" as soon as it is financially beneficial to the owners.  Still, I wish I was there - bleacher seats are quite affordable and a lot of fun at the (former) Jake.

From what I understand, the economy in Cleveland (and greater Ohio) continues to be a shambles. The team's always had a very loyal, die-hard fan base. But who knows how many of those fans and their families are too poor to afford tickets, or have moved themselves to Texas or North Dakota, seeking work.

The team also alienated its fans with its glacial and inept re-building of the past ten years. Remember this team had rebuilt to the point of having CC Sabathia and Cliff Lee, just entering into their primes, and they sold the players off. Now Indians fans get to look around the league and see what their rebuilding period loyalty got them.

Finally, though most of us reading this aren't from Ohio or Cleveland necessarily, it's not that tough to think back exactly one year: The Indians were great for the first half of last season (I believe they led the AL in wins through May), and just as they began to generate some buzz within the city, they completely folded after the All-Star break. With the exception of the new catcher, Santana, Shin-Soo Choo and Perez, they also have no real stars.

The part that probably hurts most for the team is the huge number of empty seats in Jacobs Field. Attendance figures aren't the same as turnstile counts, and it's obvious throughout the league this season that attendance is down everywhere. I wouldn't be surprised if that 14,000 estimate in fact equals around 10,000 actually showing up.

I am a school teacher, but that is not the focus of my comment.   My husband is a small business owner, and hiring two more employees would close his business down.  As it is, in order to keep the business going in these poor economic times, he does not draw a salary so that the three existing employees he has can remain employed.  At this point in time, the business does not generate enough work to warrant the hiring of two more.  Before politicians and other pundits make grand statements about “hiring at least two more workers,” perhaps they should discuss their ideas with true small business owners.  It might work for Apple or Microsoft or Monsanto, but not for true Mom-and-Pop small businesses.

EDoug and Janet - People are not being hired because there is not enough demand. It has nothing to do with taxes. Even if you hand cash to a business owner, he is not going to use it to hire more workers to make more widgets or serve more meals if he can't sell more widgets or meals. Corporations are sitting on TRILLIONS of cash, but are not using it to hire more or pay their workers more because there is not enough demand and too many workers.

Only government can provide well-paying jobs, which as a side effect will improve the country. Hire back the teachers and other government workers (at all levels) who have been fired. Fix our roads and bridges. Rebuild our power grid. Not only would you be putting peole back to work and increasing demand, but you would be helping the country with more teachers and better infrastructure.

And most importantly, you would be starting a posi5ive feedback loop. As more people get better paying jobs and start buying more stuff, businesses would hire more people to make and serve more stuff and we would get even more people who can buy stuff, and so on.

What the Republicans have been doing is the opposite, starting a negative feedback loop, where government workers are fired and needed projects are cancelled (see Christie, Chris) so there are fewer people able to buy stuff and this has led to layoffs, etc., etc., etc.

We have a great opportunity to finance this program since the government can sell bonds that pay negative real interest.

I realize there are many businesses that cannot hire additional workers. That is the case with my own very small business at the moment. What was being suggested was the idea of encouraging businesses to hire and making public acknowledgement of those actions.

When businesses hire, more money goes into circulation and more businesses can then, of necessity, hire. Various estimates show American business sitting on more than 2 trillion dollars of capital (I don't have the exact figure at hand).

In the past, we have overcome some of our national problems by creating an atmosphere of cooperation to move beyond the mindset of depression or recession. It might not have always worked perfectly, but it does give people a sense of movement and improvement.

First, on the idea of encouraging businesses, large or small, to add employees: this is not a bad idea. My wife, Janet Terry, has been suggesting the same thing since the start of the recession and she comes up with some pretty good ideas, despite sharing a house with me. An organized program of hiring encouraged by mild tax breaks and public recognition, could put a dent in the jobs recession.

Education cannot be "reformed", saved or made wonderful. There are too many cooks stirring the pot. Ideas that work and prove successful, instead of being adopted widely, are routinely rejected by school districts and states because they, themselves, want to claim the credit for anything that is successful.

The idea of testing 3rd graders within an inch of their lives is so bad that it might have been thought up by Dracula. Accountability has become a mantra, but the main effect is to terrorize students and sap teacher's creativity. We know, however, that not enough good results are coming out of the pipeline as dropouts increase, colleges dumb down their classes, students in college study much less and not enough people are qualified for good jobs.

All students should have publicly provided vouchers. When they arrive at their school, those vouchers would allow for direct improvements in education. Kids from poorer districts and poor families should get vouchers worth twice as much. Students would represent an asset, not just problems with two legs.

Interesting observation you make. I noticed recently that I have stopped "seeing" the ads and I couldn't tell you exactly when this happened. Oh yes, they are there on the periphery of my consciousness, maybe blinking and animating away, but I have stopped processing them. They are pretty much background noise.

Check your fridge or your bathroom, and tell me that advertising doesn't work for you.  Those things blinking away in the periphery are working their way into your subconscious, so when you actually see the brand, it is "known" to you.  Unfamiliarity is the biggest barrier to sales.

There was plenty to read advising caution before the shares of Facebook became public, not the least of which was an outrageous 'price to earnings ratio' of 100 with the shares priced at $38, compared to a PE of 13.8 for Apple. I find FB deadly dull, many sharing ironic moments of bedroom and business, to excruciating details of what their latest drink is from Starbucks.

In fairness, there are many worthwhile causes shown on Facebook, wonderful musicians and other artistic people, but much of the content seems not so stimulating at all. Like many, I see the ads on the margin, but have become so inundated with ads in my lifetime from so many sources that I simply ignore them.

Graduates are a product of the educational system and the culture in which the grow up and the values they take from them. Insitutions, policies, behaviors at home, in school, in the village square, in politics and in business-large and small-shape the young minds and their lives. The Open Letter by Mohit Chandra is addressing the system more than the graduates except the point about th knowledge and use of English as an international language of business.
Policy makers in the Indian education system and the economic system should pay attention to what Mohit Chandra is saying for India to be a significant player on global scale. If we accept Mr. Chandra's numbers, 10 percent of graduates in India (and 50 percent of the 30 million diaspora Indians around the globe-my estimate) are doing fine. Thank you.
More of the young graduates, and by implication India, would do much better if the system follows the advice given by Mr. Chandra. He is thinking out of the box and has shared his assessment whatever its limitations. Reforms should follow for a better future for the graduates, the companies they work for and the societies they live in.
